down.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to or towards a lower place or position
down.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: David bent down to tie his shoelace.
Tears were streaming down my face.
The sun was going down and it would soon be dark.
They came running down the stairs.
She stood on a balcony looking down into the courtyard.
Glancing down the list of runners, I noticed a familiar name.
Her hair came down to her waist.
Ken fell asleep face down  (=with his face towards the ground) on the couch.
down.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: in a lower place or position
down.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: We heard the sound of laughter down below.
The bathroom is down those stairs.
Halfway down the page, there was the item I was looking for.
down.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: into a sitting or lying position
down.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: I think I’ll go and lie down for a while.
down.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: at or to a place that is further along something such as a road or path
down.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: A young man came hurrying down the street.
She looked down the road to see if anyone was coming.
There is a pleasant little cafe bar a hundred yards down the road.
The bus stop is a bit further down on the left-hand side.
down.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: They drove all the way down from Boston to Miami.
They sailed down the east coast of Africa.
Now he’s bought a villa down south.
down.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: at or to a place that is not far away
down.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: She’s just gone down to the shops.
I saw her down at the station this morning.
down.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: away from the place where a river starts
down.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: Chunks of ice came floating down the river.
down.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: used with verbs that mean ‘fasten’ to show that something is fastened firmly to the surface or object below it
down.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: The coffin lid had been nailed down.
down.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: at or towards a level or amount that is less
down.translation[0].definitions[8].examp: House prices have come down in recent months.
Sharif cut his report down to only three pages.
down.translation[0].definitions[9].defin: losing to an opponent by a certain number of points
down.translation[0].definitions[9].examp: Swindon were six points down at one stage.
two goals down/three points down etc
down.translation[0].definitions[10].defi: used with verbs that mean ‘write’ to show that you write something on paper or in a book
down.translation[0].definitions[10].exam: I’ll write down the address for you.
Start by jotting down a few ideas.
Let’s put you down as self-employed.
down.translation[0].definitions[11].defi: if you are down for something, your name is on a list of people who want to do something or are intended to do something
down.translation[0].definitions[11].exam: Purvis is down for the 200 metre freestyle event.
We’ve already put his name down for nursery school.
I’ve got you down to do the table decorations.
down.translation[0].definitions[12].defi: from an earlier time in history to a later time or to people who are born in later times
down.translation[0].definitions[12].exam: a person whose words and actions have inspired millions of people down the centuries
This knowledge was handed down in the family from father to son.
The story has been passed down the generations for a thousand years.
traditions that have come down to us from medieval times
down.translation[0].definitions[13].exam: A top quality freezer for only £20 down and £5 a week for a year.
down.translation[0].definitions[14].exam: I want you to wash my car down.
down.translation[0].definitions[15].defi: in or into your stomach as a result of swallowing
down.translation[0].definitions[15].exam: Meg’s been very ill and can’t keep her food down.
down.translation[0].definitions[17].defi: if a computer is down, it is not working
down.translation[0].definitions[18].defi: used to say that someone leaves or has left a university at the end of a period of study
down.translation[0].definitions[18].exam: Sarah came down from Oxford in 1966.
down.translation[0].definitions[19].exam: Well, you’ve passed your second test, so it’s two down and four more to go.
down.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: used to tell a jumping dog to get down
down.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: to drink or eat something quickly
down.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: He downed the coffee in one gulp.
down.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: to knock or force someone to the ground
down.translation[2].definitions[1].examp: O'Malley downed his opponent in the first round.
down.translation[3].definitions[1].defin: the soft fine feathers of a bird
down.translation[3].definitions[2].defin: one of the four chances that an American football team has to move forward when it is their turn to have the ball
down.translation[4].definitions[0].defin: at or towards the bottom or end of something
down.translation[4].definitions[0].examp: downriver  (=nearer to where it goes into the sea)
down.translation[4].definitions[1].defin: used to show that something is being made smaller or less important
down.translation[4].definitions[1].examp: to downgrade a job  (=make it less important)
to downsize a company  (=reduce the number of jobs in it)
down.translation[4].definitions[2].defin: used to show that something is bad or negative
down.translation[4].definitions[2].examp: the downside of a situation  (=the negative part of it)
down.translation[5].definitions[0].defin: if an amount or the level of something goes down, it falls to a lower amount or level
down.translation[5].definitions[0].examp: By lunchtime, the 100-index was down 4.2 at 3053.1.
59% of companies report sales volume down on a year ago.
The cuts have taken the company’s UK workforce down by 30%
down.translation[5].definitions[1].defin: money paid as a first payment towards a larger sum. Cash down can also mean paying for something immediately in notes and coins rather than with a cheque
down.translation[5].definitions[1].examp: The sum of money to be paid is $50 cash down and ten monthly installments of $5.
down.translation[5].definitions[2].defin: if a machine, system, or piece of electrical equipment is down, it is not working
down.translation[5].definitions[2].examp: My system went down over the weekend and I didn’t get any emails.
The printer can be used even when the telecommunication lines are down.
down.translation[6].definitions[0].defin: if the people who work in a factory down tools, they refuse to work
down.translation[6].definitions[0].examp: Workers downed tools in protest against the redundancies.
